instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]No green light on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Hello, on this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PP3V42 is 1,394V. Resistance to GND is 0,309V. <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is 1,38V and resistance to GND is 0,465. I checked <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area, because the two signals show up there together. <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> has 5V on both sides, <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> is 4,3V, <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> is 16,6V so everything looks fine here for me. Pins 2 (PP3V42) and 4 of J6100 look a little burned (just a little black touch, but visible). Also <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> Pin 1-4 look a little bad. (as if there is nearly no solder on them compared to Pins 5-8) but maybe thats just my eyes tricking me. The machine was used in a "slightly wet" environment (tropic climate), but no evidence of water. his is one of the cleanest machines/ boards i´ve ever seen.

threads.title: [SOLVED]No green light on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
[SOLVED]No green light on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: No 3V42 so check voltage on pin 6 <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>. Check for corrosion around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> in general.

threads.title: [SOLVED]No green light on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I replaced <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> wit another diode with equal size. Now <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is there but jumping between 1,8V and 3,3V. Diode Mode reading is 1,115V. PP3V42 is ok. Is this indicating a problem with the SMC?

threads.title: [SOLVED]No green light on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: sorry wrong post...Due to human verification i mixed the pages up...

threads.title: [SOLVED]No green light on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I have no idea what you are doing. First 3V42 is not there, now you are replacing <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>, why?

threads.title: [SOLVED]No green light on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I`m really sorry about that. I posted my answer in the wrong Tab. I must have mixed the tabs up as i logged off and back in for human verification and copied the message. It should be in my "<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light" post i also have open right now. I posted it there now. Meanwhile i could fix this one. I don´t know how i could miss this the first time. It was a dead <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>. 16V at Pin 6 and 8 and no output. So sorry again for wasting your time and thank you very much for the help!

threads.title: [SOLVED]No green light on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
[SOLVED]No green light on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Yes. everything seems to work fine now. Thank you!
